instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.ONOFF_L: What is ONOFF_L? This is a abbreviation of SMC_ONOFF_L.When you see ONOFF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Damage around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Area repaired.

PBUS G3H - 8.56
PP3V42- 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
PPRTC - 3.324
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 0.009V

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> PIN 4 <SIGNAL>PP5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> missing

.427 in diode  PP5VS4RS3

Thanks for any help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see if get a drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If not, check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and all (4) RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the ISL normal? Must have been corrosion elsewhere all the normal culprits apply SMC <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> BIOS and it?s traces/resistors etc

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
I was able to turn on once in what I think was SMC Bypass by holding power down for  10 secs then releasing and hitting power again. (It was no chime and no light on mouse)  got fan spin and 1.8v on vcore. I have not been able to get it to turn on again. This being a 2015, does  need to have battery plugged in to it to turn on? Please clarify how to get into SMC Bypass please on this particular board so that i can rule it out, and move on to the measurements you asked for...

17/18 , 27/28 is right where it should be. 

Thanks again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s...

"17/18 , 27/28 is right where it should be."
On <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

Measure mentioned signals with board in off state.
We need to see which signal blocks the board to start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Yes on ISL, sorry. 

OK, thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.412V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0.036V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - fluctuates 3.1v - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.407v, goes down to 0.357v when SMC_ <SIGNAL>ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.

Have a great night.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0.036V"
First try original Apple 60W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Update with 60W Genuine charger - <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  stays between 2.298v and 3.301v

I was using a genuine 85W Apple charger. My mistake, sorry.

Take care.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Does it work with this charger?
If not, post results for above mentioned measurements...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
No change with different charger unfortunately...

New measurements -

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.412V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.315V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - Fluctuates - 3.12 - 3.14V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.408v, goes down to 0.353V when SMC_ <SIGNAL>ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.412V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> - fluctuates between 2.3V and 2.5V

I dont have a scope to give signals, sorry.

Thanks or the help, take care.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
"and all (4) RTC signals."
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.
No o-scpoe needed, just DC voltage...

"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.408v, goes down to 0.353V when SMC_ <SIGNAL>ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered."
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at least, at the same moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message: Ok, thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses .907V when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered. 

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.250V

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.250V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 2.760V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> -  1.85V - 1.89V 

This board powered up for me when I first came in this morning. Now it wont of course.

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 1.85V - 1.89V"
Are you sure?
That is too low...

First check <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>.
If OK, put quality flux and heat PCH.
You may have luck and there is just some crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - (1.9V to 2.1V)

Though <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> looked fine and measured correctly, I replaced anyway, now getting 2.2V

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> pulses when I first plug in the charger. 

Tried the flux under board with no success

Since you led me to <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> I noticed that the TP next to the CPU\PCH was slightly burnt.  I tinned the pad but still no success.
(I know I should have noticed this sooner but if you hadn't led me there I wouldn't have known.)

With the burnt TP I'm guessing PCH is done...

Thanks for all your help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Try lower value for <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>, 470-100K.
Let see if starts if you get aprox 2.4V at <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi - Got <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> up to 2.490V, still nothing. The voltage isn't steady. Sometimes when I take the measurement it goes to 2.8V sometime 2.2V. Either way no fan spin. 

Thanks man. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message: This looks like bad PCH indeed...
